case_name: Corporation of Calcutta v. owners of premises No. 296, Bowbazzar Street, Calcutta

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 268 of 1958 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 268 of 1958.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and decree dated June 15, 1956 of Calcutta High Court in Appeal from Original Order No. 349 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated June 15,1956, of the Calcutta High Court in Appeal from Original order No. 349 of 1953.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on August 8, 1961 by SUBBA RAO, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. August 8. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SUBBA RAO, J.-This appeal by certificate

facts.text: Respondents are owners of premises No. 296, Bowbazzar Street, Calcutta.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents are the owners of premises No. 296, Bowbazzar Street, Calcutta. The Corporation of Calcutta fixed

facts.text: Corporation of Calcutta fixed annual valuation of premises at Rs. 14,093 effective from second quarter of 1950-51.

anchor.surface_text: The Corporation of Calcutta fixed the annual valuation of the said premises at a sum of Rs. 14,093 and directed the same to take effect from the second quarter of 1950-51.

facts.text: Annual valuation based on Rs. 1,450 as monthly rental value.

anchor.surface_text: In fixing the annual valuation, the said Corporation took as basis Rs. 1,450 as the monthly rental value of the premises.

facts.text: Notice of assessment served on respondents on June 20, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: On June 20, 1950, numberice of the assessment based on the said annual valuation was served on the respondents.

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 filed objections under s. 139 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 1 filed objections to the said assessment under s. 139 of the Act.

facts.text: Standard rent fixed by Rent Controller at Rs. 550 per month from April 1951 under West Bengal Premises Rent Control Temporary Provisions Act, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: Meanwhile under the West Bengal Premises Rent Control  Temporary Provision  Act, 1950  W.B. XVII of 1950 ,  hereinafter called the Rent Control Act , the standard rent of the said premises was fixed by the Rent Controller the rent was fixed at Rs, 550 per month with effect from April, 1951,

facts.text: Standard rent increased to Rs. 632-8-0 per month from August 1951.

anchor.surface_text: and at Rs, 632-8-0 per month with effect from August, 1951.

facts.text: One objection was that Corporation had no power to fix annual valuation higher than standard rent.

anchor.surface_text: One of the objections raised was that the Corporation had numberpower to fix the annual valuation at a figure higher than the standard rent.

facts.text: Special Officer disallowed objections and confirmed assessment.

anchor.surface_text: The Special Officer disallowed all the objections and companyfirmed the assessment.

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 appealed to Court of Small Causes, Calcutta.

anchor.surface_text: Being aggrieved by the said order, respondent No. 1 filed an appeal in the Court of Small Causes, Calcutta,

facts.text: Small Causes Judge allowed appeal and fixed annual valuation at Rs. 6,831 based on standard rent of Rs. 632-8-0 per month.

anchor.surface_text: and the learned Small Causes Judge allowed the appeal and fixed the annual valuation, for the purpose of assessment, at Rs. 6,831. That was on the basis of the standard rent of Rs. 632-8-0 per month.

facts.text: Corporation appealed to Calcutta High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The Corporation of Calcutta questioned the companyrectness of the said Judgment by preferring an appeal to the High Court at Calcutta.

facts.text: High Court by majority agreed with Small Causes Judge and dismissed appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court by a majority agreed with the Small Causes Judge and dismissed the appeal.

facts.text: Present appeal by certificate from High Court order.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by certificate from the order of the High Court at Calcutta raises the question of the true interpretation

facts.text: Supreme Court holds that annual value cannot exceed standard rent under Rent Control Act.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, we hold, on a fair reading of the express provision of s.127  a  of the Act in the light of the decisions companysidered, that the rental value cannot be fixed higher than the standard rent under the Rent Control Act.

facts.text: West Bengal Premises Rent Control Temporary Provisions Act, 1950 (W.B. XVII of 1950) enacted.

anchor.surface_text: Meanwhile under the West Bengal Premises Rent Control  Temporary Provision  Act, 1950  W.B. XVII of 1950 ,  hereinafter called the Rent Control Act ,

facts.text: Calcutta Municipal Act, 1923 contains s.127A for annual value.

anchor.surface_text: raises the question of the true interpretation of the provisions of s. 127 a  of the Calcutta Municipal Act, 1923  hereinafter called the Act .

facts.text: C. Chatterjee and S. Ghose appeared for appellant.

anchor.surface_text: C. Chatterjee and S. Ghose, for the appellant. P. Maheshwari, for respondents Nos. 1, 2 and 4. 1961.

facts.text: P. Maheshwari appeared for respondents Nos. 1, 2 and 4.

issues.text: the true interpretation of the provisions of s. 127 a of the Calcutta Municipal Act, 1923

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by certificate from the order of the High Court at Calcutta raises the question of the true interpretation of the provisions of s. 127 a  of the Calcutta Municipal Act, 1923  hereinafter called the Act .

issues.text: the Corporation had no power to fix the annual valuation at a figure higher than the standard rent

anchor.surface_text: One of the objections raised was that the Corporation had no power to fix the annual valuation at a figure higher than the standard rent. The Special Officer disallowed all the objections and confirmed the assessment.

issues.text: under s. 127 a of the Act the Corporation has to ascertain only the hypothetical rent realisable from a hypothetical tenant at the time of assessment and not the actual rent payable at that time by any tenant, and therefore it is not bound to take into consideration the standard rent fixed under the Rent Control Act

anchor.surface_text: The main contention of Mr. N. C. Chatterjee, learned counsel for the appellant Corporation, is that under s. 127 a  of the Act the Corporation has to ascertain only the hypothetical rent realisable from a hypothetical tenant at the time of assessment and not the actual rent payable at that time by any tenant, and therefore it is not bound to take into consideration the standard rent fixed under the Rent Control Act.

issues.text: the precise meaning of the phrase 'at the time of assessment' occurring in s.127 a of the Act

anchor.surface_text: A subsidiary point raised in the appeal is as to the precise meaning of the phrase ,at the time of assessment occurring in s.127 a  of the Act.

issues.text: what is the meaning of the phrase at the time of assessment occurring in s.127 a of the Act

anchor.surface_text: The next question is, what is the meaning of the phrase at the time of assessment occurring in s.127 a  of the Act. The majority view of the High Court was that assessment commences with the making of the valuation under B. 131 of the Act

arguments.claim: The Corporation had no power to fix the annual valuation at a figure higher than the standard rent.

anchor.surface_text: One of the objections raised was that the Corporation had numberpower to fix the annual valuation at a figure higher than the standard rent. The Special Officer disa

court_response_anchor.surface_text: prohibition companytained in s.26 of the Rent Act of 1920. But that in itself cannot mean that the absence of such an express prohibition would imply

arguments.court_reasoning: Fair reading of s.127A in light of Rent Control Act provisions making excess rent irrecoverable and penal limits rental value to standard rent.

arguments.claim: Under s.127A of the Act the Corporation has to ascertain only the hypothetical rent realisable from a hypothetical tenant at the time of assessment and not the actual rent payable at that time by any tenant, and therefore it is not bound to take into consideration the standard rent fixed under the Rent Control Act.

anchor.surface_text: The main contention of Mr. N. C. Chatterjee, learned counsel for the appellant Corporation, is that under s. 127 a  of the Act the Corporation has to ascertain only the hypothetical rent realisable from a hypothetical tenant at the time of assessment and not the actual rent payable at that time by any tenant, and therefore it is not bound to take into consideration the standard rent fixed under the Rent Control Act.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ce with the provisions of s.127 a  of the Calcutta Municipal Act, 1923. There the plot in question was a vacant land occasionally used by the member o

arguments.court_reasoning: Hypothetical reasonable rent is limited by Rent Control Act's penal provisions; landlord cannot reasonably expect illegal rent exceeding standard rent.

arguments.claim: The phrase 'at the time of assessment' occurring in s.127A refers to the period commencing with valuation under s.131 and ending with determination of objections under s.140.

anchor.surface_text: The majority view of the High Court was that assessment commences with the making of the valuation under B. 131 of the Act and ends with the determination of the objection under s.140 thereof,

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ess of this view has number seriously been companytested before us. That apart, for the reasons mentioned by Lahiri and Sen, JJ., that companyclusion

arguments.court_reasoning: Correctness not seriously contested; justified by reasons of Lahiri and Sen JJ and provisions of the Act.

arguments.claim: The annual value under s.127A is the letting value to the landlord/owner, not the occupation value to the tenant.

anchor.surface_text: The dictionary meaning of the words to let, is grant use of for rent or hire. It implies that the rent which the landlord might realise if the house was let is the basis for fixing the annual value of the building. The criterion, therefore, is the rent realisable by the landlord and number the value of the, holding in the hands of the tenant.

arguments.claim: Annual value of unoccupied land cannot be based on hypothetical tenant precluded from occupying it.

anchor.surface_text: This aspect has been emphasized by the Judicial Committee in Bengal Nagpur Railway Company Limited v. Corporation of Calcutta 1 . ... It is impossible to companystrue s.127 as meaning that, when land is unoccupied, its annual value must be taken to be the rent at which it might be expected to be let to a tenant who was- precluded from occupying it.

arguments.claim: The standard of value is the value of the property to the owner, measured by rent it would be worth to a hypothetical tenant.

anchor.surface_text: The same principle was accepted by a division bench of the Madras High Court as early as 1886 in Secretary of State v. Madras Municipality , . Section 123 of the City of Madras Municipal Act  Mad. 1 of 1884  which was similar in its terms to s.127 a  of the Calcutta Municipal Act, 1.923, ran as follows .lm15 The gross annual rent at which a building or land might reasonably be expected to let from month to month or from year to year shall for the purposes of assessment under this Act be deemed to be the annual value of such building or land.

arguments.claim: A landlord cannot reasonably be expected to let for rent higher than standard rent under Rent Control Act due to irrecoverability (s.3) and penalties (s.33A).

anchor.surface_text: Under the Rent Control Act, the receipt of any rent higher than the standard rent fixed under the Act is made penal for the landlord. Section 3 of the said Act says that any amount in excess of the standard rent of any premises shall be irrecoverable notwithstanding any agreement to the contrary. Section 33 a  thereof provides inter alia that ,whoever knowingly receives, whether directly or indirectly, any sum on account of the rent of any premises in excess of the standard rent

arguments.claim: Standard rent limits valuation for rating as per Rent Restrictions Act (contra to majority).

anchor.surface_text: If numberhigher rent than the standard rent and statutory increases is enforceable, as a matter of common sense that seems to be the limit of the rent a tenant can be reasonably expected to give How then is the annual rent to be ascertained ? It is obvious that the definition presupposes that the premises are deemed to be vacant and are deemed to be capable of being let.

arguments.court_reasoning: Agrees with Atkin LJ observations approved by Lord Carson.

arguments.claim: In Poplar case, standard rent does not limit gross value for rating.

anchor.surface_text: Strong reliance is placed by learned counsel for the appellant on the decision of the House of Lords in Poplar Assessment Committee v. Roberts 1  in support of the contention that the standard rent fixed under the Rent Control Act shall number be taken into account in determining the valuation for rating purposes.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: pon the peculiar aspect of the English Law of rating. Lord Buckmaster stated ,From the earliest time it is the inhabitant who has to be taxed. It is i

arguments.court_reasoning: English rating based on occupation value, Indian on letting value to owner; English excess rent not penal unlike India.

arguments.claim: English rating law taxes beneficial occupation of tenant, distinct from value to owner.

anchor.surface_text: Lord Buckmaster stated ,From the earliest time it is the inhabitant who has to be taxed. It is in respect of his occupation that the rate is levied, and the standard in the Act is numberhing but a means of finding out what the value of that occupation is for the purposes of assessment. Lord Atkinson observed What the ratepayer is, under both the Act of 1836 and that of 1869, rated in respect of is decided by many cases in this House to be the beneficial occupation of a hereditament.

arguments.claim: Omission of explicit prohibition like s.26 of 1920 Rent Act implies power to assess higher than standard rent.

anchor.surface_text: Nor are we impressed by the argument that the omission of a specific provision, as in s.26 of the Calcutta Rent Act of 1920, prohibiting the Calcutta Corporation from making assessment of any rent higher than the rent fixed by the Rent Controller in the subsequent Acts would inevitably lead to the conclusion that the omission implies the conferment of such a power.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: tion. In the result, we hold, on a fair reading of the express provision of s.127  a  of the Act in the light of the decisions companysidered, that th

arguments.court_reasoning: Intention from words of s.127A, not other Acts; later 1951 Act makes implicit explicit; no implied conferment.

arguments.claim: Fixing annual value higher than standard rent allowable as s.9(1)(b) Rent Control allows increase for taxes/rates.

anchor.surface_text: It is said that, as under s. 9 1  b  of the Rent Control Act the landlord can get the standard rent raised by an amount equivalent to the increase in taxes, rates or cesses, there would number be any prejudice even if the annual value of the building is fixed on the basis of a rate of rent higher than that permissible under the said Act.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: mentioned that in the subsequent Acts there was numberprohibition similar to that companytained in s. 26 of the Calcutta Rent Act of 1920. It may also

arguments.court_reasoning: Leads to vicious circle circumventing Rent Control; confines s.9(1)(b) to actual tax increases.

arguments.claim: Hypothetical rent in open market excludes black market/illegal rents beyond statutory limit.

anchor.surface_text: But an open market cannot include a ,,black market, a term euphemistically used to commercial transactions entered into between. parties in defiance of law. In that situation, a statutory limitation of rent circumscribes the scope of the bargain in the market. In numbercircumstances the hypothetical rent can exceed that limit.

holdings.text: on a fair reading of the express provision of s.127 a of the Act in the light of the decisions considered, that the rental value cannot be fixed higher than the standard rent under the Rent Control Act

anchor.surface_text: In the result, we hold, on a fair reading of the express provision of s.127 a of the Act in the light of the decisions considered, that the rental value cannot be fixed higher than the standard rent under the Rent Control Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.127A requires gross annual rent reasonably expected to let; reasonableness limited by Rent Control Act making excess irrecoverable (s.3) and penal (s.33A); hypothetical open market excludes illegal black market rents

holdings.text: the value of the property to the owner is the standard in making the assessment thereunder

anchor.surface_text: We, would, with respect, accept the said principle in the construction of the said section and hold that the value of the property to the owner is the standard in making the assessment thereunder. The word reasonably in the section throws further light on this interpretation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dictionary meaning of 'to let'; approved Judicial Committee in Bengal Nagpur Railway and Madras High Court; criterion is rent realisable by landlord not value to tenant

holdings.text: a statutory limitation of rent circumscribes the scope of the bargain in the market. In no circumstances the hypothetical rent can exceed that limit

anchor.surface_text: But an open market cannot include a black market, a term euphemistically used to commercial transactions entered into between parties in defiance of law. In that situation, a statutory limitation of rent circumscribes the scope of the bargain in the market. In no circumstances the hypothetical rent can exceed that limit.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Hypothetical rent in open market excludes defiance of law; Rent Control Act limits enforceable rent

holdings.text: assessment commences with the making of the valuation under s. 131 of the Act and ends with the determination of the objection under s.140 thereof, and that an event which took place during this period may be relied upon for assessing the annual value under s.127 a of the Act

anchor.surface_text: The majority view of the High Court was that assessment commences with the making of the valuation under s. 131 of the Act and ends with the determination of the objection under s.140 thereof, and that an event which took place during this period may be relied upon for assessing the annual value under s.127 a of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Correctness not contested; justified by reasons of Lahiri and Sen JJ and provisions of the Act

holdings.text: the majority view can easily be distinguished on the peculiar principle of rating obtaining in England which is fundamentally different from that accepted under the Act

anchor.surface_text: That is why, while in England the value of occupation by a tenant is the criterion for fixing the standard rent under the rating law, under the Act the letting value of a building to the landlord is the standard in fixing the rental value. If this distinction is borne in mind much of the cloud cast in this case is dispelled.

holdings.reasoning_summary: English rating taxes beneficial occupation (Poplar case); Indian taxes letting value to owner; excess rent penal in India unlike England

precedents.citation: Bengal Nagpur Railway Company Limited v. Corporation of Calcutta 1 1946 L. R. 74 1. A. 1.

anchor.surface_text: Bengal Nagpur Railway Company Limited v. Corporation of Calcutta 1 . The question for determination in that case was whether the assessment of a certain premises to the companysolidated rate was made in accordance with the provisions of s.127 a  of the Calcutta Municipal Act, 1923.

precedents.case_name: Bengal Nagpur Railway Company Limited v Corporation of Calcutta
precedents.cited_proposition: criterion is the rent realisable by the landlord and not the value of the holding in the hands of the tenant; land owned is assessable even if vacant
precedents.cited_holding: It is impossible to construe s.127 as meaning that, when land is unoccupied, its annual value must be taken to be the rent at which it might be expected to be let to a tenant who was precluded from occupying it.

precedents.citation: Secretary of State v. Madras Municipality 1 1886 I.L.R. 10 Mad. 38.

anchor.surface_text: Secretary of State v. Madras Municipality , . Section 123 of the City of Madras Municipal Act  Mad. 1 of 1884  which was similar in its terms to s.127 a  of the Calcutta Municipal Act, 1.923, ran as follows .lm15 The gross annual rent at which a building or land might reasonably be expected to let from month to month or from year to year shall for the purposes of assessment under this Act be deemed to be the annual value of such building or land.

precedents.case_name: Secretary of State v Madras Municipality
precedents.cited_proposition: value of the property to the owner measured by rent it would be worth to a hypothetical tenant
precedents.cited_holding: The standard of value is certainly the value of the property to the owner which is to be measured, whether he occupies the property himself or lets it out to a tenant by the amount of rent per annum it would be worth to a hypothetical tenant.

precedents.citation: Corporation-of Calcutta v. Ashutosh De 1 1927 31 C.W.N. 864.

anchor.surface_text: Mukherjee, J., in Corporation-of Calcutta v. Ashutosh De  1 , accepted the said principle and applied the same in construing s.127 a  of the Act though Roy, J., differed from him. We, would, with respect, accept the said principle in the construction of the said section and hold that the value of the property to the owner is the standard in making the assessment thereunder.

precedents.case_name: Corporation of Calcutta v Ashutosh De
precedents.cited_proposition: value of the property to the owner is the standard in construing s.127 a

precedents.cited_proposition: standard rent does not limit the gross value for rating purposes

anchor.surface_text: the distinction between the English and the Indian law which has already been pointed out by the Judicial Committee in Bengal Nagpur Railway Company Limited v. Corporation of Calcutta  1 . That is why, while in England the value of occupation by a tenant is the criterion for fixing the, standard rent under the rating law, under the Act the letting value of a building to the landlord is the standard in fixing the, rental value.

precedents.case_name: Bengal Nagpur Railway Company Limited v Corporation of Calcutta
precedents.cited_proposition: distinction between English and Indian law on rating: letting value to landlord vs occupation value to tenant

The Surati Bara Bazzar Company Limited  4  and the Calcutta High Court in the present case distinguished the said decision. We would prefer to accept the view expressed by the Calcutta and Rangoon High Courts, is the decisions of the said Courts are based upon a correct appreciation of the distinction between the law of rating in England and that under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: We, would, with respect, accept the said principle in the construction of the said section and hold that the value of the property to the owner is the standard in making the assessment thereunder. The word reasonably in the section throws further light on this interpretation.

In the result, we hold, on a fair reading of the express provision of s.127 a  of the Act in the light of the decisions considered, that the rental value cannot be fixed higher than the standard rent under the Rent Control Act.

anchor.surface_text: But an open market cannot include a black market, a term euphemistically used to commercial transactions entered into between parties in defiance of law. In that situation, a statutory limitation of rent circumscribes the scope of the bargain in the market. In no circumstances the hypothetical rent can exceed that limit.

In the result, we hold, on a fair reading of the express provision of s.127 a  of the Act in the light of the decisions considered, that the rental value cannot be fixed higher than the standard rent under the Rent Control Act.

anchor.surface_text: The majority view of the High Court was that assessment commences with the making of the valuation under s. 131 of the Act and ends with the determination of the objection under s.140 thereof, and that an event which took place during this period may be relied upon for assessing the annual value under s.127 a of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: That is why, while in England the value of occupation by a tenant is the criterion for fixing the standard rent under the rating law, under the Act the letting value of a building to the landlord is the standard in fixing the rental value. If this distinction is borne in mind much of the cloud cast in this case is dispelled.

In the result, we hold, on a fair reading of the express provision of s.127 a  of the Act in the light of the decisions considered, that the rental value cannot be fixed higher than the standard rent under the Rent Control Act.
